name: Radiation-Induced Brachial Plexopathy
chief_complaint: I have weakness and numbness in my arm that's getting worse, and it started after my radiation treatments.
physical_findings: absent deep tendon reflexes in affected arm

lab_results.EMG: evidence of denervation in brachial plexus distribution
lab_results.MRI: fibrosis and atrophy of brachial plexus without tumor recurrence

treatment: physical therapy to maintain range of motion
prognosis: Variable; typically progressive with incomplete recovery. Early intervention may slow progression but complete reversal is uncommon. Quality of life can be maintained with proper symptom management.
description: A delayed complication of radiation therapy (typically appearing 6 months to several years post-treatment) characterized by progressive fibrosis and damage to the brachial plexus nerves. Most commonly occurs after radiation for breast cancer, lung cancer, or lymphoma. Pathophysiology involves a combination of direct nerve damage, vascular insufficiency, and fibrotic entrapment.
risk_factors: presence of diabetes or vascular disease
